     464             : #ifndef WIN32
     465             :     {"sysv", SHMEM_TYPE_SYSV, false},
     466             : #endif
     467             : #ifndef EXEC_BACKEND
     468             :     {"mmap", SHMEM_TYPE_MMAP, false},
     469             : #endif
     470             : #ifdef WIN32
     471             :     {"windows", SHMEM_TYPE_WINDOWS, false},
     472             : #endif
     473             :     {NULL, 0, false}
     474             : };
     475             : 
     476             : /*
     477             :  * Options for enum values stored in other modules
     478             :  */
     479             : extern const struct config_enum_entry wal_level_options[];
     480             : extern const struct config_enum_entry archive_mode_options[];
     481             : extern const struct config_enum_entry recovery_target_action_options[];
     482             : extern const struct config_enum_entry sync_method_options[];
     483             : extern const struct config_enum_entry dynamic_shared_memory_options[];
     484             : 
     485             : /*
     486             :  * GUC option variables that are exported from this module
     487             :  */
     488             : bool        log_duration = false;
     489             : bool        Debug_print_plan = false;
     490             : bool        Debug_print_parse = false;
     491             : bool        Debug_print_rewritten = false;

     498             :                                              * together */
     499             : bool        log_btree_build_stats = false;
     500             : char       *event_source;
     501             : 
     502             : bool        row_security;
     503             : bool        check_function_bodies = true;
     504             :

     507             :  * details.
     508             :  */
     509             : bool        default_with_oids = false;
     510             : bool        session_auth_is_superuser;
     511             : 
     512             : int         log_min_error_statement = ERROR;
     513             : int         log_min_messages = WARNING;
     514             : int         client_min_messages = NOTICE;
     515             : int         log_min_duration_sample = -1;
     516             : int         log_min_duration_statement = -1;
     517             : int         log_temp_files = -1;

     519             : double      log_xact_sample_rate = 0;
     520             : int         trace_recovery_messages = LOG;

     522             : char       *backtrace_symbol_list;
     523             :

     537             : 
     538             : int         tcp_keepalives_idle;

     540             : int         tcp_keepalives_count;
     541             : int         tcp_user_timeout;
     542             : 
     543             : /*
     544             :  * SSL renegotiation was been removed in PostgreSQL 9.5, but we tolerate it
     545             :  * being set to zero (meaning never renegotiate) for backward compatibility.
     546             :  * This avoids breaking compatibility with clients that have never supported
     547             :  * renegotiation and therefore always try to zero it.
     548             :  */
     549             : int         ssl_renegotiation_limit;
     550             : 
     551             : /*
     552             :  * This really belongs in pg_shmem.c, but is defined here so that it doesn't
     553             :  * need to be duplicated in all the different implementations of pg_shmem.c.
     554             :  */
     555             : int         huge_pages;
     556             : 
     557             : /*
     558             :  * These variables are all dummies that don't do anything, except in some
     559             :  * cases provide the value for SHOW to display.  The real state is elsewhere
     560             :  * and is kept in sync by assign_hooks.
     561             :  */
     562             : static char *syslog_ident_str;
     563             : static double phony_random_seed;
     564             : static char *client_encoding_string;
     565             : static char *datestyle_string;
     566             : static char *locale_collate;
     567             : static char *locale_ctype;

     569             : static char *server_version_string;
     570             : static int  server_version_num;
     571             : static char *timezone_string;
     572             : static char *log_timezone_string;

     578             : static int  max_identifier_length;
     579             : static int  block_size;

     582             : static bool data_checksums;

     745             : 
     746             : /*
     747             :  * Displayable names for GUC variable types (enum config_type)
     748             :  *
     749             :  * Note: these strings are deliberately not localized.
     750             :  */
     751             : const char *const config_type_names[] =
     752             : {
     753             :      /* PGC_BOOL */ "bool",
     754             :      /* PGC_INT */ "integer",
     755             :      /* PGC_REAL */ "real",
     756             :      /* PGC_STRING */ "string",
     757             :      /* PGC_ENUM */ "enum"
     758             : };
     759             : 
     760             : /*
     761             :  * Unit conversion tables.
     762             :  *
     763             :  * There are two tables, one for memory units, and another for time units.
     764             :  * For each supported conversion from one unit to another, we have an entry
     765             :  * in the table.
     766             :  *
     767             :  * To keep things simple, and to avoid possible roundoff error,
     768             :  * conversions are never chained.  There needs to be a direct conversion
     769             :  * between all units (of the same type).
     770             :  *
     771             :  * The conversions for each base unit must be kept in order from greatest to
     772             :  * smallest human-friendly unit; convert_xxx_from_base_unit() rely on that.
     773             :  * (The order of the base-unit groups does not matter.)
     774             :  */
     775             : #define MAX_UNIT_LEN        3   /* length of longest recognized unit string */
     776             : 
     777             : typedef struct
     778             : {
     779             :     char        unit[MAX_UNIT_LEN + 1]; /* unit, as a string, like "kB" or
     780             :                                          * "min" */
     781             :     int         base_unit;      /* GUC_UNIT_XXX */
     782             :     double      multiplier;     /* Factor for converting unit -> base_unit */
     783             : } unit_conversion;
     784             : 
     785             : /* Ensure that the constants in the tables don't overflow or underflow */
     786             : #if BLCKSZ < 1024 || BLCKSZ > (1024*1024)
     787             : #error BLCKSZ must be between 1KB and 1MB
     788             : #endif
     789             : #if XLOG_BLCKSZ < 1024 || XLOG_BLCKSZ > (1024*1024)
     790             : #error XLOG_BLCKSZ must be between 1KB and 1MB
     791             : #endif
     792             : 
     793             : static const char *memory_units_hint = gettext_noop("Valid units for this parameter are \"B\", \"kB\", \"MB\", \"GB\", and \"TB\".");
     794             : 
     795             : static const unit_conversion memory_unit_conversion_table[] =
     796             : {
     797             :     {"TB", GUC_UNIT_BYTE, 1024.0 * 1024.0 * 1024.0 * 1024.0},
     798             :     {"GB", GUC_UNIT_BYTE, 1024.0 * 1024.0 * 1024.0},
     799             :     {"MB", GUC_UNIT_BYTE, 1024.0 * 1024.0},
     800             :     {"kB", GUC_UNIT_BYTE, 1024.0},
     801             :     {"B", GUC_UNIT_BYTE, 1.0},
     802             : 
     803             :     {"TB", GUC_UNIT_KB, 1024.0 * 1024.0 * 1024.0},
     804             :     {"GB", GUC_UNIT_KB, 1024.0 * 1024.0},
     805             :     {"MB", GUC_UNIT_KB, 1024.0},
     806             :     {"kB", GUC_UNIT_KB, 1.0},
     807             :     {"B", GUC_UNIT_KB, 1.0 / 1024.0},
     808             : 
     809             :     {"TB", GUC_UNIT_MB, 1024.0 * 1024.0},
     810             :     {"GB", GUC_UNIT_MB, 1024.0},
     811             :     {"MB", GUC_UNIT_MB, 1.0},
     812             :     {"kB", GUC_UNIT_MB, 1.0 / 1024.0},
     813             :     {"B", GUC_UNIT_MB, 1.0 / (1024.0 * 1024.0)},
     814             : 
     815             :     {"TB", GUC_UNIT_BLOCKS, (1024.0 * 1024.0 * 1024.0) / (BLCKSZ / 1024)},
     816             :     {"GB", GUC_UNIT_BLOCKS, (1024.0 * 1024.0) / (BLCKSZ / 1024)},
     817             :     {"MB", GUC_UNIT_BLOCKS, 1024.0 / (BLCKSZ / 1024)},
     818             :     {"kB", GUC_UNIT_BLOCKS, 1.0 / (BLCKSZ / 1024)},
     819             :     {"B", GUC_UNIT_BLOCKS, 1.0 / BLCKSZ},
     820             : 
     821             :     {"TB", GUC_UNIT_XBLOCKS, (1024.0 * 1024.0 * 1024.0) / (XLOG_BLCKSZ / 1024)},
     822             :     {"GB", GUC_UNIT_XBLOCKS, (1024.0 * 1024.0) / (XLOG_BLCKSZ / 1024)},
     823             :     {"MB", GUC_UNIT_XBLOCKS, 1024.0 / (XLOG_BLCKSZ / 1024)},
     824             :     {"kB", GUC_UNIT_XBLOCKS, 1.0 / (XLOG_BLCKSZ / 1024)},
     825             :     {"B", GUC_UNIT_XBLOCKS, 1.0 / XLOG_BLCKSZ},
     826             : 
     827             :     {""}                      /* end of table marker */
     828             : };
     829             : 
     830             : static const char *time_units_hint = gettext_noop("Valid units for this parameter are \"us\", \"ms\", \"s\", \"min\", \"h\", and \"d\".");
     831             : 
     832             : static const unit_conversion time_unit_conversion_table[] =
     833             : {
     834             :     {"d", GUC_UNIT_MS, 1000 * 60 * 60 * 24},
     835             :     {"h", GUC_UNIT_MS, 1000 * 60 * 60},
     836             :     {"min", GUC_UNIT_MS, 1000 * 60},
     837             :     {"s", GUC_UNIT_MS, 1000},
     838             :     {"ms", GUC_UNIT_MS, 1},
     839             :     {"us", GUC_UNIT_MS, 1.0 / 1000},
     840             : 
     841             :     {"d", GUC_UNIT_S, 60 * 60 * 24},
     842             :     {"h", GUC_UNIT_S, 60 * 60},
     843             :     {"min", GUC_UNIT_S, 60},
     844             :     {"s", GUC_UNIT_S, 1},
     845             :     {"ms", GUC_UNIT_S, 1.0 / 1000},
     846             :     {"us", GUC_UNIT_S, 1.0 / (1000 * 1000)},
     847             : 
     848             :     {"d", GUC_UNIT_MIN, 60 * 24},
     849             :     {"h", GUC_UNIT_MIN, 60},
     850             :     {"min", GUC_UNIT_MIN, 1},
     851             :     {"s", GUC_UNIT_MIN, 1.0 / 60},
     852             :     {"ms", GUC_UNIT_MIN, 1.0 / (1000 * 60)},
     853             :     {"us", GUC_UNIT_MIN, 1.0 / (1000 * 1000 * 60)},
     854             : 
     855             :     {""}                      /* end of table marker */
     856             : };
     857             : 
     858             : /*
     859             :  * Contents of GUC tables
     860             :  *
     861             :  * See src/backend/utils/misc/README for design notes.
     862             :  *
     863             :  * TO ADD AN OPTION:
     864             :  *
     865             :  * 1. Declare a global variable of type bool, int, double, or char*
     866             :  *    and make use of it.
     867             :  *
     868             :  * 2. Decide at what times it's safe to set the option. See guc.h for
     869             :  *    details.
     870             :  *
     871             :  * 3. Decide on a name, a default value, upper and lower bounds (if
     872             :  *    applicable), etc.
     873             :  *
     874             :  * 4. Add a record below.
     875             :  *
     876             :  * 5. Add it to src/backend/utils/misc/postgresql.conf.sample, if
     877             :  *    appropriate.
     878             :  *
     879             :  * 6. Don't forget to document the option (at least in config.sgml).
     880             :  *
     881             :  * 7. If it's a new GUC_LIST_QUOTE option, you must add it to
     882             :  *    variable_is_guc_list_quote() in src/bin/pg_dump/dumputils.c.
     883             :  */
     884             : 
     885             : 
     886             : /******** option records follow ********/
     887             : 
     888             : static struct config_bool ConfigureNamesBool[] =
     889             : {
     890             :     {
     891             :         {"enable_seqscan", PGC_USERSET, QUERY_TUNING_METHOD,
     892             :             gettext_noop("Enables the planner's use of sequential-scan plans."),
     893             :             NULL,
     894             :             GUC_EXPLAIN
     895             :         },
     896             :         &enable_seqscan,
     897             :         true,
     898             :         NULL, NULL, NULL
     899             :     },
     900             :     {
     901             :         {"enable_indexscan", PGC_USERSET, QUERY_TUNING_METHOD,
     902             :             gettext_noop("Enables the planner's use of index-scan plans."),
     903             :             NULL,
     904             :             GUC_EXPLAIN
     905             :         },
     906             :         &enable_indexscan,
     907             :         true,
     908             :         NULL, NULL, NULL
     909             :     },
     910             :     {
     911             :         {"enable_indexonlyscan", PGC_USERSET, QUERY_TUNING_METHOD,
     912             :             gettext_noop("Enables the planner's use of index-only-scan plans."),
     913             :             NULL,
     914             :             GUC_EXPLAIN
     915             :         },
     916             :         &enable_indexonlyscan,
     917             :         true,
     918             :         NULL, NULL, NULL
     919             :     },
     920             :     {
     921             :         {"enable_bitmapscan", PGC_USERSET, QUERY_TUNING_METHOD,
     922             :             gettext_noop("Enables the planner's use of bitmap-scan plans."),
     923             :             NULL,
     924             :             GUC_EXPLAIN
     925             :         },
     926             :         &enable_bitmapscan,
     927             :         true,
     928             :         NULL, NULL, NULL
     929             :     },
     930             :     {
     931             :         {"enable_tidscan", PGC_USERSET, QUERY_TUNING_METHOD,
     932             :             gettext_noop("Enables the planner's use of TID scan plans."),
     933             :             NULL,
     934             :             GUC_EXPLAIN
     935             :         },
     936             :         &enable_tidscan,
     937             :         true,
     938             :         NULL, NULL, NULL
     939             :     },
     940             :     {
     941             :         {"enable_sort", PGC_USERSET, QUERY_TUNING_METHOD,
     942             :             gettext_noop("Enables the planner's use of explicit sort steps."),
     943             :             NULL,
     944             :             GUC_EXPLAIN
     945             :         },
     946             :         &enable_sort,
     947             :         true,
     948             :         NULL, NULL, NULL
     949             :     },
     950             :     {
     951             :         {"enable_hashagg", PGC_USERSET, QUERY_TUNING_METHOD,
     952             :             gettext_noop("Enables the planner's use of hashed aggregation plans."),
     953             :             NULL,
     954             :             GUC_EXPLAIN
     955             :         },
     956             :         &enable_hashagg,
     957             :         true,
     958             :         NULL, NULL, NULL
     959             :     },
     960             :     {
     961             :         {"enable_material", PGC_USERSET, QUERY_TUNING_METHOD,
     962             :             gettext_noop("Enables the planner's use of materialization."),
     963             :             NULL,
     964             :             GUC_EXPLAIN
     965             :         },
     966             :         &enable_material,
     967             :         true,
     968             :         NULL, NULL, NULL
     969             :     },
     970             :     {
     971             :         {"enable_nestloop", PGC_USERSET, QUERY_TUNING_METHOD,
     972             :             gettext_noop("Enables the planner's use of nested-loop join plans."),
     973             :             NULL,
     974             :             GUC_EXPLAIN
     975             :         },
     976             :         &enable_nestloop,
     977             :         true,
     978             :         NULL, NULL, NULL
     979             :     },
     980             :     {

    1145             :                          "report an error, aborting the current transaction. Setting "
    1146             :                          "ignore_checksum_failure to true causes the system to ignore the failure "
    1147             :                          "(but still report a warning), and continue processing. This "
    1148             :                          "behavior could cause crashes or other serious problems. Only "
    1149             :                          "has an effect if checksums are enabled."),

    1161             :                          "zero_damaged_pages to true causes the system to instead report a "
    1162             :                          "warning, zero out the damaged page, and continue processing. This "
    1163             :                          "behavior will destroy data, namely all the rows on the damaged page."),
    1164             :             GUC_NOT_IN_SAMPLE

    1176             :                          "pages when first modified after a checkpoint to WAL so full recovery "
    1177             :                          "is possible.")

    1521             :             gettext_noop("When turned on, expressions of the form expr = NULL "
    1522             :                          "(or NULL = expr) are treated as expr IS NULL, that is, they "
    1523             :                          "return true if expr evaluates to the null value, and false "
    1524             :                          "otherwise. The correct behavior of expr = NULL is to always "
    1525             :                          "return null (unknown).")
    1526             :         },

    1534             :             NULL

    1967             : 
    1968             : 
    1969             : static struct config_int ConfigureNamesInt[] =
    1970             : {
    1971             :     {
    1972             :         {"archive_timeout", PGC_SIGHUP, WAL_ARCHIVING,
    1973             :             gettext_noop("Forces a switch to the next WAL file if a "
    1974             :                          "new file has not been started within N seconds."),
    1975             :             NULL,
    1976             :             GUC_UNIT_S
    1977             :         },
    1978             :         &XLogArchiveTimeout,
    1979             :         0, 0, INT_MAX / 2,
    1980             :         NULL, NULL, NULL
    1981             :     },
    1982             :     {
    1983             :         {"post_auth_delay", PGC_BACKEND, DEVELOPER_OPTIONS,
    1984             :             gettext_noop("Waits N seconds on connection startup after authentication."),
    1985             :             gettext_noop("This allows attaching a debugger to the process."),
    1986             :             GUC_NOT_IN_SAMPLE | GUC_UNIT_S
    1987             :         },
    1988             :         &PostAuthDelay,
    1989             :         0, 0, INT_MAX / 1000000,
    1990             :         NULL, NULL, NULL
    1991             :     },
    1992             :     {
    1993             :         {"default_statistics_target", PGC_USERSET, QUERY_TUNING_OTHER,
    1994             :             gettext_noop("Sets the default statistics target."),
    1995             :             gettext_noop("This applies to table columns that have not had a "
    1996             :                          "column-specific target set via ALTER TABLE SET STATISTICS.")
    1997             :         },
    1998             :         &default_statistics_target,
    1999             :         100, 1, 10000,
    2000             :         NULL, NULL, NULL
    2001             :     },
    2002             :     {
    2003             :         {"from_collapse_limit", PGC_USERSET, QUERY_TUNING_OTHER,
    2004             :             gettext_noop("Sets the FROM-list size beyond which subqueries "
    2005             :                          "are not collapsed."),
    2006             :             gettext_noop("The planner will merge subqueries into upper "
    2007             :                          "queries if the resulting FROM list would have no more than "
    2008             :                          "this many items."),
    2009             :             GUC_EXPLAIN
    2010             :         },
    2011             :         &from_collapse_limit,
    2012             :         8, 1, INT_MAX,
    2013             :         NULL, NULL, NULL
    2014             :     },
    2015             :     {
    2016             :         {"join_collapse_limit", PGC_USERSET, QUERY_TUNING_OTHER,
    2017             :             gettext_noop("Sets the FROM-list size beyond which JOIN "
    2018             :                          "constructs are not flattened."),
    2019             :             gettext_noop("The planner will flatten explicit JOIN "
    2020             :                          "constructs into lists of FROM items whenever a "
    2021             :                          "list of no more than this many items would result."),
    2022             :             GUC_EXPLAIN
    2023             :         },
    2024             :         &join_collapse_limit,
    2025             :         8, 1, INT_MAX,
    2026             :         NULL, NULL, NULL
    2027             :     },
    2028             :     {
    2029             :         {"geqo_threshold", PGC_USERSET, QUERY_TUNING_GEQO,
    2030             :             gettext_noop("Sets the threshold of FROM items beyond which GEQO is used."),
    2031             :             NULL,
    2032             :             GUC_EXPLAIN
    2033             :         },
    2034             :         &geqo_threshold,
    2035             :         12, 2, INT_MAX,
    2036             :         NULL, NULL, NULL
    2037             :     },
    2038             :     {
    2039             :         {"geqo_effort", PGC_USERSET, QUERY_TUNING_GEQO,

    2048             :     {

    2051             :             gettext_noop("Zero selects a suitable default value."),
    2052             :             GUC_EXPLAIN
    2053             :         },

    2056             :         NULL, NULL, NULL

    2058             :     {

    2061             :             gettext_noop("Zero selects a suitable default value."),
    2062             :             GUC_EXPLAIN

    2066             :         NULL, NULL, NULL

    2068             : 
    2069             :     {
    2070             :         /* This is PGC_SUSET to prevent hiding from log_lock_waits. */
    2071             :         {"deadlock_timeout", PGC_SUSET, LOCK_MANAGEMENT,
    2072             :             gettext_noop("Sets the time to wait on a lock before checking for deadlock."),
    2073             :             NULL,

    2080             : 
    2081             :     {
    2082             :         {"max_standby_archive_delay", PGC_SIGHUP, REPLICATION_STANDBY,
    2083             :             gettext_noop("Sets the maximum delay before canceling queries when a hot standby server is processing archived WAL data."),
    2084             :             NULL,
    2085             :             GUC_UNIT_MS
    2086             :         },

    3121             :                          "system default."),

    4601             : 
    4602             : /*
    4603             :  * To allow continued support of obsolete names for GUC variables, we apply
    4604             :  * the following mappings to any unrecognized name.  Note that an old name
    4605             :  * should be mapped to a new one only if the new variable has very similar
    4606             :  * semantics to the old.
    4607             :  */
    4608             : static const char *const map_old_guc_names[] = {
    4609             :     "sort_mem", "work_mem",
    4610             :     "vacuum_mem", "maintenance_work_mem",
    4611             :     NULL
    4612             : };

    4658             : /*
    4659             :  * Some infrastructure for checking malloc/strdup/realloc calls
    4660             :  */
    4661             : static void *
    4662       26548 : guc_malloc(int elevel, size_t size)
    4663             : {
    4664             :     void       *data;
    4665             : 
    4666             :     /* Avoid unportable behavior of malloc(0) */
    4667       26548 :     if (size == 0)
    4668           0 :         size = 1;
    4669       26548 :     data = malloc(size);
    4670       26548 :     if (data == NULL)
    4671           0 :         ereport(elevel,
    4672             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_OUT_OF_MEMORY),
    4673             :                  errmsg("out of memory")));
    4674       26548 :     return data;
    4675             : }
    4676             : 
    4677             : static void *
    4678           0 : guc_realloc(int elevel, void *old, size_t size)
    4679             : {
    4680             :     void       *data;
    4681             : 
    4682             :     /* Avoid unportable behavior of realloc(NULL, 0) */
    4683           0 :     if (old == NULL && size == 0)
    4684           0 :         size = 1;
    4685           0 :     data = realloc(old, size);
    4686           0 :     if (data == NULL)
    4687           0 :         ereport(elevel,
    4688             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_OUT_OF_MEMORY),
    4689             :                  errmsg("out of memory")));
    4690           0 :     return data;
    4691             : }
    4692             : 
    4693             : static char *
    4694      177482 : guc_strdup(int elevel, const char *src)
    4695             : {
    4696             :     char       *data;
    4697             : 
    4698      177482 :     data = strdup(src);
    4699      177482 :     if (data == NULL)
    4700           0 :         ereport(elevel,
    4701             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_OUT_OF_MEMORY),
    4702             :                  errmsg("out of memory")));
    4703      177482 :     return data;
    4704             : }
    4705             : 
    4706             : 
    4707             : /*
    4708             :  * Detect whether strval is referenced anywhere in a GUC string item
    4709             :  */
    4710             : static bool
    4711      118546 : string_field_used(struct config_string *conf, char *strval)
    4712             : {
    4713             :     GucStack   *stack;

    5132             : /*
    5133             :  * the bare comparison function for GUC names
    5134             :  */
    5135             : static int
    5136    19671466 : guc_name_compare(const char *namea, const char *nameb)
    5137             : {
    5138             :     /*
    5139             :      * The temptation to use strcasecmp() here must be resisted, because the
    5140             :      * array ordering has to remain stable across setlocale() calls. So, build
    5141             :      * our own with a simple ASCII-only downcasing.
    5142             :      */
    5143   102412558 :     while (*namea && *nameb)
    5144             :     {
    5145    82113872 :         char        cha = *namea++;
    5146    82113872 :         char        chb = *nameb++;
    5147             : 
    5148    82113872 :         if (cha >= 'A' && cha <= 'Z')
    5149      235078 :             cha += 'a' - 'A';
    5150    82113872 :         if (chb >= 'A' && chb <= 'Z')
    5151      142566 :             chb += 'a' - 'A';
    5152    82113872 :         if (cha != chb)
    5153    19044246 :             return cha - chb;
    5154             :     }
    5155      627220 :     if (*namea)
    5156       72264 :         return 1;               /* a is longer */
    5157      554956 :     if (*nameb)
    5158      398472 :         return -1;              /* b is longer */
    5159      156484 :     return 0;
    5160             : }

    5215             : 
    5216             : /*
    5217             :  * Assign any GUC values that can come from the server's environment.
    5218             :  *
    5219             :  * This is called from InitializeGUCOptions, and also from ProcessConfigFile
    5220             :  * to deal with the possibility that a setting has been removed from
    5221             :  * postgresql.conf and should now get a value from the environment.
    5222             :  * (The latter is a kludge that should probably go away someday; if so,
    5223             :  * fold this back into InitializeGUCOptions.)
    5224             :  */
    5225             : static void

    5237        1228 :         SetConfigOption("datestyle", env, PGC_POSTMASTER, PGC_S_ENV_VAR);

    5662             : /*
    5663             :  * push_old_value
    5664             :  *      Push previous state during transactional assignment to a GUC variable.
    5665             :  */
    5666             : static void
    5667       11016 : push_old_value(struct config_generic *gconf, GucAction action)
    5668             : {
    5669             :     GucStack   *stack;
    5670             : 
    5671             :     /* If we're not inside a nest level, do nothing */
    5672       11016 :     if (GUCNestLevel == 0)
    5673           0 :         return;
    5674             : 
    5675             :     /* Do we already have a stack entry of the current nest level? */
    5676       11016 :     stack = gconf->stack;
    5677       11016 :     if (stack && stack->nest_level >= GUCNestLevel)
    5678             :     {
    5679             :         /* Yes, so adjust its state if necessary */
    5680        2080 :         Assert(stack->nest_level == GUCNestLevel);
    5681        2080 :         switch (action)
    5682             :         {
    5683             :             case GUC_ACTION_SET:
    5684             :                 /* SET overrides any prior action at same nest level */
    5685        2068 :                 if (stack->state == GUC_SET_LOCAL)
    5686             :                 {
    5687             :                     /* must discard old masked value */
    5688           0 :                     discard_stack_value(gconf, &stack->masked);
    5689             :                 }
    5690        2068 :                 stack->state = GUC_SET;
    5691        2068 :                 break;
    5692             :             case GUC_ACTION_LOCAL:
    5693          12 :                 if (stack->state == GUC_SET)
    5694             :                 {
    5695             :                     /* SET followed by SET LOCAL, remember SET's value */
    5696           4 :                     stack->masked_scontext = gconf->scontext;
    5697           4 :                     set_stack_value(gconf, &stack->masked);
    5698           4 :                     stack->state = GUC_SET_LOCAL;
    5699             :                 }
    5700             :                 /* in all other cases, no change to stack entry */
    5701          12 :                 break;
    5702             :             case GUC_ACTION_SAVE:
    5703             :                 /* Could only have a prior SAVE of same variable */
    5704           0 :                 Assert(stack->state == GUC_SAVE);
    5705           0 :                 break;
    5706             :         }
    5707        2080 :         Assert(guc_dirty);      /* must be set already */
    5708        2080 :         return;
    5709             :     }
    5710             : 
    5711             :     /*
    5712             :      * Push a new stack entry
    5713             :      *
    5714             :      * We keep all the stack entries in TopTransactionContext for simplicity.
    5715             :      */
    5716        8936 :     stack = (GucStack *) MemoryContextAllocZero(TopTransactionContext,
    5717             :                                                 sizeof(GucStack));
    5718             : 
    5719        8936 :     stack->prev = gconf->stack;
    5720        8936 :     stack->nest_level = GUCNestLevel;
    5721        8936 :     switch (action)
    5722             :     {
    5723             :         case GUC_ACTION_SET:
    5724        8372 :             stack->state = GUC_SET;
    5725        8372 :             break;
    5726             :         case GUC_ACTION_LOCAL:
    5727         256 :             stack->state = GUC_LOCAL;
    5728         256 :             break;
    5729             :         case GUC_ACTION_SAVE:
    5730         308 :             stack->state = GUC_SAVE;
    5731         308 :             break;
    5732             :     }
    5733        8936 :     stack->source = gconf->source;
    5734        8936 :     stack->scontext = gconf->scontext;

    5738             : 
    5739             :     /* Ensure we remember to pop at end of xact */
    5740        8936 :     guc_dirty = true;

    5743             : 
    5744             : /*
    5745             :  * Do GUC processing at main transaction start.
    5746             :  */
    5747             : void
    5748       71316 : AtStart_GUC(void)
    5749             : {
    5750             :     /*
    5751             :      * The nest level should be 0 between transactions; if it isn't, somebody
    5752             :      * didn't call AtEOXact_GUC, or called it with the wrong nestLevel.  We
    5753             :      * throw a warning but make no other effort to clean up.
    5754             :      */

    5756           0 :         elog(WARNING, "GUC nest level = %d at transaction start",
    5757             :              GUCNestLevel);
    5758       71316 :     GUCNestLevel = 1;
    5759       71316 : }
    5760             : 
    5761             : /*
    5762             :  * Enter a new nesting level for GUC values.  This is called at subtransaction
    5763             :  * start, and when entering a function that has proconfig settings, and in
    5764             :  * some other places where we want to set GUC variables transiently.
    5765             :  * NOTE we must not risk error here, else subtransaction start will be unhappy.
    5766             :  */
    5767             : int
    5768       10766 : NewGUCNestLevel(void)
    5769             : {
    5770       10766 :     return ++GUCNestLevel;
    5771             : }
    5772             : 
    5773             : /*
    5774             :  * Do GUC processing at transaction or subtransaction commit or abort, or
    5775             :  * when exiting a function that has proconfig settings, or when undoing a
    5776             :  * transient assignment to some GUC variables.  (The name is thus a bit of
    5777             :  * a misnomer; perhaps it should be ExitGUCNestLevel or some such.)
    5778             :  * During abort, we discard all GUC settings that were applied at nesting
    5779             :  * levels >= nestLevel.  nestLevel == 1 corresponds to the main transaction.
    5780             :  */
    5781             : void
    5782       81944 : AtEOXact_GUC(bool isCommit, int nestLevel)

    6107             : 
    6108             : /*
    6109             :  * Convert a value from one of the human-friendly units ("kB", "min" etc.)
    6110             :  * to the given base unit.  'value' and 'unit' are the input value and unit
    6111             :  * to convert from (there can be trailing spaces in the unit string).
    6112             :  * The converted value is stored in *base_value.
    6113             :  * It's caller's responsibility to round off the converted value as necessary
    6114             :  * and check for out-of-range.
    6115             :  *
    6116             :  * Returns true on success, false if the input unit is not recognized.
    6117             :  */
    6118             : static bool
    6119        5016 : convert_to_base_unit(double value, const char *unit,
    6120             :                      int base_unit, double *base_value)
    6121             : {
    6122             :     char        unitstr[MAX_UNIT_LEN + 1];
    6123             :     int         unitlen;
    6124             :     const unit_conversion *table;
    6125             :     int         i;
    6126             : 
    6127             :     /* extract unit string to compare to table entries */
    6128        5016 :     unitlen = 0;
    6129       20062 :     while (*unit != '\0' && !isspace((unsigned char) *unit) &&
    6130             :            unitlen < MAX_UNIT_LEN)
    6131       10030 :         unitstr[unitlen++] = *(unit++);
    6132        5016 :     unitstr[unitlen] = '\0';
    6133             :     /* allow whitespace after unit */
    6134       10032 :     while (isspace((unsigned char) *unit))
    6135           0 :         unit++;
    6136        5016 :     if (*unit != '\0')
    6137           0 :         return false;           /* unit too long, or garbage after it */
    6138             : 
    6139             :     /* now search the appropriate table */
    6140        5016 :     if (base_unit & GUC_UNIT_MEMORY)
    6141        5012 :         table = memory_unit_conversion_table;
    6142             :     else
    6143           4 :         table = time_unit_conversion_table;
    6144             : 
    6145       64698 :     for (i = 0; *table[i].unit; i++)
    6146             :     {
    6147       79796 :         if (base_unit == table[i].base_unit &&
    6148       15098 :             strcmp(unitstr, table[i].unit) == 0)
    6149             :         {
    6150        5016 :             double      cvalue = value * table[i].multiplier;
    6151             : 
    6152             :             /*
    6153             :              * If the user gave a fractional value such as "30.1GB", round it
    6154             :              * off to the nearest multiple of the next smaller unit, if there
    6155             :              * is one.
    6156             :              */
    6157       10032 :             if (*table[i + 1].unit &&
    6158        5016 :                 base_unit == table[i + 1].base_unit)
    6159       10028 :                 cvalue = rint(cvalue / table[i + 1].multiplier) *
    6160        5014 :                     table[i + 1].multiplier;
    6161             : 
    6162        5016 :             *base_value = cvalue;
    6163        5016 :             return true;
    6164             :         }
    6165             :     }
    6166           0 :     return false;
    6167             : }
    6168             : 
    6169             : /*
    6170             :  * Convert an integer value in some base unit to a human-friendly unit.
    6171             :  *
    6172             :  * The output unit is chosen so that it's the greatest unit that can represent
    6173             :  * the value without loss.  For example, if the base unit is GUC_UNIT_KB, 1024
    6174             :  * is converted to 1 MB, but 1025 is represented as 1025 kB.
    6175             :  */
    6176             : static void
    6177          30 : convert_int_from_base_unit(int64 base_value, int base_unit,
    6178             :                            int64 *value, const char **unit)
    6179             : {
    6180             :     const unit_conversion *table;
    6181             :     int         i;
    6182             : 
    6183          30 :     *unit = NULL;
    6184             : 
    6185          30 :     if (base_unit & GUC_UNIT_MEMORY)
    6186          30 :         table = memory_unit_conversion_table;
    6187             :     else
    6188           0 :         table = time_unit_conversion_table;
    6189             : 
    6190         240 :     for (i = 0; *table[i].unit; i++)
    6191             :     {
    6192         240 :         if (base_unit == table[i].base_unit)
    6193             :         {
    6194             :             /*
    6195             :              * Accept the first conversion that divides the value evenly.  We
    6196             :              * assume that the conversions for each base unit are ordered from
    6197             :              * greatest unit to the smallest!
    6198             :              */
    6199         180 :             if (table[i].multiplier <= 1.0 ||
    6200          90 :                 base_value % (int64) table[i].multiplier == 0)
    6201             :             {
    6202          30 :                 *value = (int64) rint(base_value / table[i].multiplier);
    6203          30 :                 *unit = table[i].unit;
    6204          30 :                 break;
    6205             :             }
    6206             :         }
    6207             :     }
    6208             : 
    6209          30 :     Assert(*unit != NULL);
    6210          30 : }
    6211             : 
    6212             : /*
    6213             :  * Convert a floating-point value in some base unit to a human-friendly unit.
    6214             :  *
    6215             :  * Same as above, except we have to do the math a bit differently, and
    6216             :  * there's a possibility that we don't find any exact divisor.
    6217             :  */
    6218             : static void
    6219          88 : convert_real_from_base_unit(double base_value, int base_unit,
    6220             :                             double *value, const char **unit)
    6221             : {
    6222             :     const unit_conversion *table;
    6223             :     int         i;
    6224             : 
    6225          88 :     *unit = NULL;
    6226             : 
    6227          88 :     if (base_unit & GUC_UNIT_MEMORY)
    6228           0 :         table = memory_unit_conversion_table;
    6229             :     else
    6230          88 :         table = time_unit_conversion_table;
    6231             : 
    6232         448 :     for (i = 0; *table[i].unit; i++)
    6233             :     {
    6234         448 :         if (base_unit == table[i].base_unit)
    6235             :         {
    6236             :             /*
    6237             :              * Accept the first conversion that divides the value evenly; or
    6238             :              * if there is none, use the smallest (last) target unit.
    6239             :              *
    6240             :              * What we actually care about here is whether snprintf with "%g"
    6241             :              * will print the value as an integer, so the obvious test of
    6242             :              * "*value == rint(*value)" is too strict; roundoff error might
    6243             :              * make us choose an unreasonably small unit.  As a compromise,
    6244             :              * accept a divisor that is within 1e-8 of producing an integer.
    6245             :              */
    6246         448 :             *value = base_value / table[i].multiplier;
    6247         448 :             *unit = table[i].unit;
    6248         896 :             if (*value > 0 &&
    6249         448 :                 fabs((rint(*value) / *value) - 1.0) <= 1e-8)
    6250          88 :                 break;
    6251             :         }
    6252             :     }
    6253             : 
    6254          88 :     Assert(*unit != NULL);
    6255          88 : }
    6256             : 
    6257             : /*

    6305             : 
    6306             : /*
    6307             :  * Try to parse value as an integer.  The accepted formats are the
    6308             :  * usual decimal, octal, or hexadecimal formats, as well as floating-point
    6309             :  * formats (which will be rounded to integer after any units conversion).
    6310             :  * Optionally, the value can be followed by a unit name if "flags" indicates
    6311             :  * a unit is allowed.
    6312             :  *
    6313             :  * If the string parses okay, return true, else false.
    6314             :  * If okay and result is not NULL, return the value in *result.
    6315             :  * If not okay and hintmsg is not NULL, *hintmsg is set to a suitable
    6316             :  * HINT message, or NULL if no hint provided.
    6317             :  */
    6318             : bool
    6319       20692 : parse_int(const char *value, int *result, int flags, const char **hintmsg)

    6321             :     /*
    6322             :      * We assume here that double is wide enough to represent any integer

    6559             : /*
    6560             :  * Parse and validate a proposed value for the specified configuration
    6561             :  * parameter.
    6562             :  *
    6563             :  * This does built-in checks (such as range limits for an integer parameter)
    6564             :  * and also calls any check hook the parameter may have.
    6565             :  *

    6567             :  * name: variable name (should match the record of course)
    6568             :  * value: proposed value, as a string

    6573             :  *  (caller must initialize *newextra to NULL)

    6737             : 
    6738             : 
    6739             : /*
    6740             :  * Sets option `name' to given value.
    6741             :  *
    6742             :  * The value should be a string, which will be parsed and converted to
    6743             :  * the appropriate data type.  The context and source parameters indicate
    6744             :  * in which context this function is being called, so that it can apply the
    6745             :  * access restrictions properly.
    6746             :  *
    6747             :  * If value is NULL, set the option to its default value (normally the
    6748             :  * reset_val, but if source == PGC_S_DEFAULT we instead use the boot_val).
    6749             :  *
    6750             :  * action indicates whether to set the value globally in the session, locally
    6751             :  * to the current top transaction, or just for the duration of a function call.
    6752             :  *
    6753             :  * If changeVal is false then don't really set the option but do all
    6754             :  * the checks to see if it would work.
    6755             :  *
    6756             :  * elevel should normally be passed as zero, allowing this function to make
    6757             :  * its standard choice of ereport level.  However some callers need to be
    6758             :  * able to override that choice; they should pass the ereport level to use.
    6759             :  *
    6760             :  * Return value:
    6761             :  *  +1: the value is valid and was successfully applied.
    6762             :  *  0:  the name or value is invalid (but see below).
    6763             :  *  -1: the value was not applied because of context, priority, or changeVal.
    6764             :  *
    6765             :  * If there is an error (non-existing option, invalid value) then an
    6766             :  * ereport(ERROR) is thrown *unless* this is called for a source for which
    6767             :  * we don't want an ERROR (currently, those are defaults, the config file,
    6768             :  * and per-database or per-user settings, as well as callers who specify
    6769             :  * a less-than-ERROR elevel).  In those cases we write a suitable error
    6770             :  * message via ereport() and return 0.
    6771             :  *
    6772             :  * See also SetConfigOption for an external interface.
    6773             :  */
    6774             : int
    6775       94096 : set_config_option(const char *name, const char *value,
    6776             :                   GucContext context, GucSource source,
    6777             :                   GucAction action, bool changeVal, int elevel,
    6778             :                   bool is_reload)
    6779             : {
    6780             :     struct config_generic *record;
    6781             :     union config_var_val newval_union;
    6782       94096 :     void       *newextra = NULL;
    6783       94096 :     bool        prohibitValueChange = false;
    6784             :     bool        makeDefault;
    6785             : 
    6786       94096 :     if (elevel == 0)
    6787             :     {
    6788       69294 :         if (source == PGC_S_DEFAULT || source == PGC_S_FILE)
    6789             :         {
    6790             :             /*
    6791             :              * To avoid cluttering the log, only the postmaster bleats loudly

    6793             :              */

    6795             :         }

    6801             :         else

    6803             :     }
    6804             : 
    6805             :     /*
    6806             :      * GUC_ACTION_SAVE changes are acceptable during a parallel operation,
    6807             :      * because the current worker will also pop the change.  We're probably
    6808             :      * dealing with a function having a proconfig entry.  Only the function's
    6809             :      * body should observe the change, and peer workers do not share in the
    6810             :      * execution of a function call started by this worker.
    6811             :      *
    6812             :      * Other changes might need to affect other workers, so forbid them.
    6813             :      */
    6814       94096 :     if (IsInParallelMode() && changeVal && action != GUC_ACTION_SAVE)
    6815           0 :         ereport(elevel,
    6816             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_INVALID_TRANSACTION_STATE),
    6817             :                  errmsg("cannot set parameters during a parallel operation")));

    6819       94096 :     record = find_option(name, true, elevel);

    6821             :     {
    6822           0 :         ereport(elevel,
    6823             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_UNDEFINED_OBJECT),

    6826             :     }

    6845       14722 :             if (context == PGC_SIGHUP)
    6846             :             {

    6848             :                  * We are re-reading a PGC_POSTMASTER variable from
    6849             :                  * postgresql.conf.  We can't change the setting, so we should
    6850             :                  * give a warning if the DBA tries to change it.  However,
    6851             :                  * because of variant formats, canonicalization by check
    6852             :                  * hooks, etc, we can't just compare the given string directly
    6853             :                  * to what's stored.  Set a flag to check below after we have

    6877             :             /*

    6879             :              * can be changed after postmaster start". But there's nothing
    6880             :              * that prevents a crafty administrator from sending SIGHUP
    6881             :              * signals to individual backends only.

    6891             :                                 name)));

    6893             :             }
    6894             :             /* fall through to process the same as PGC_BACKEND */

    6896             :         case PGC_BACKEND:
    6897           0 :             if (context == PGC_SIGHUP)
    6898             :             {
    6899             :                 /*
    6900             :                  * If a PGC_BACKEND or PGC_SU_BACKEND parameter is changed in
    6901             :                  * the config file, we want to accept the new value in the
    6902             :                  * postmaster (whence it will propagate to
    6903             :                  * subsequently-started backends), but ignore it in existing
    6904             :                  * backends.  This is a tad klugy, but necessary because we
    6905             :                  * don't re-read the config file during backend start.
    6906             :                  *
    6907             :                  * In EXEC_BACKEND builds, this works differently: we load all
    6908             :                  * non-default settings from the CONFIG_EXEC_PARAMS file
    6909             :                  * during backend start.  In that case we must accept
    6910             :                  * PGC_SIGHUP settings, so as to have the same value as if
    6911             :                  * we'd forked from the postmaster.  This can also happen when
    6912             :                  * using RestoreGUCState() within a background worker that
    6913             :                  * needs to have the same settings as the user backend that
    6914             :                  * started it. is_reload will be true when either situation
    6915             :                  * applies.
    6916             :                  */
    6917           0 :                 if (IsUnderPostmaster && !is_reload)
    6918           0 :                     return -1;
    6919             :             }

    6946             : 
    6947             :     /*
    6948             :      * Disallow changing GUC_NOT_WHILE_SEC_REST values if we are inside a
    6949             :      * security restriction context.  We can reject this regardless of the GUC
    6950             :      * context or source, mainly because sources that it might be reasonable
    6951             :      * to override for won't be seen while inside a function.
    6952             :      *
    6953             :      * Note: variables marked GUC_NOT_WHILE_SEC_REST should usually be marked
    6954             :      * GUC_NO_RESET_ALL as well, because ResetAllOptions() doesn't check this.
    6955             :      * An exception might be made if the reset value is assumed to be "safe".
    6956             :      *
    6957             :      * Note: this flag is currently used for "session_authorization" and
    6958             :      * "role".  We need to prohibit changing these inside a local userid
    6959             :      * context because when we exit it, GUC won't be notified, leaving things
    6960             :      * out of sync.  (This could be fixed by forcing a new GUC nesting level,
    6961             :      * but that would change behavior in possibly-undesirable ways.)  Also, we
    6962             :      * prohibit changing these in a security-restricted operation because
    6963             :      * otherwise RESET could be used to regain the session user's privileges.
    6964             :      */
    6965       94096 :     if (record->flags & GUC_NOT_WHILE_SEC_REST)

    7548             : 
    7549             : /*
    7550             :  * Fetch the current value of the option `name', as a string.
    7551             :  *
    7552             :  * If the option doesn't exist, return NULL if missing_ok is true (NOTE that
    7553             :  * this cannot be distinguished from a string variable with a NULL value!),
    7554             :  * otherwise throw an ereport and don't return.
    7555             :  *
    7556             :  * If restrict_privileged is true, we also enforce that only superusers and
    7557             :  * members of the pg_read_all_settings role can see GUC_SUPERUSER_ONLY
    7558             :  * variables.  This should only be passed as true in user-driven calls.
    7559             :  *
    7560             :  * The string is *not* allocated for modification and is really only
    7561             :  * valid until the next call to configuration related functions.
    7562             :  */

    7687             : /*
    7688             :  * flatten_set_variable_args
    7689             :  *      Given a parsenode List as emitted by the grammar for SET,
    7690             :  *      convert to the flat string representation used by GUC.
    7691             :  *
    7692             :  * We need to be told the name of the variable the args are for, because
    7693             :  * the flattening rules vary (ugh).

    7695             :  * The result is NULL if args is NIL (i.e., SET ... TO DEFAULT), otherwise
    7696             :  * a palloc'd string.
    7697             :  */

    7699        4196 : flatten_set_variable_args(const char *name, List *args)
    7700             : {

    7815             : /*
    7816             :  * Write updated configuration parameter values into a temporary file.
    7817             :  * This function traverses the list of parameters and quotes the string
    7818             :  * values before writing them.
    7819             :  */
    7820             : static void
    7821           0 : write_auto_conf_file(int fd, const char *filename, ConfigVariable *head)
    7822             : {
    7823             :     StringInfoData buf;

    7825             : 
    7826           0 :     initStringInfo(&buf);
    7827             : 
    7828             :     /* Emit file header containing warning comment */
    7829           0 :     appendStringInfoString(&buf, "# Do not edit this file manually!\n");
    7830           0 :     appendStringInfoString(&buf, "# It will be overwritten by the ALTER SYSTEM command.\n");
    7831             : 
    7832           0 :     errno = 0;
    7833           0 :     if (write(fd, buf.data, buf.len) != buf.len)
    7834             :     {
    7835             :         /* if write didn't set errno, assume problem is no disk space */
    7836           0 :         if (errno == 0)
    7837           0 :             errno = ENOSPC;

    7946             : /*
    7947             :  * Execute ALTER SYSTEM statement.
    7948             :  *
    7949             :  * Read the old PG_AUTOCONF_FILENAME file, merge in the new variable value,
    7950             :  * and write out an updated file.  If the command is ALTER SYSTEM RESET ALL,
    7951             :  * we can skip reading the old file and just write an empty file.
    7952             :  *
    7953             :  * An LWLock is used to serialize updates of the configuration file.
    7954             :  *
    7955             :  * In case of an error, we leave the original automatic
    7956             :  * configuration file (PG_AUTOCONF_FILENAME) intact.
    7957             :  */

    8364             :     /* Note SET DEFAULT (argstring == NULL) is equivalent to RESET */
    8365           0 :     (void) set_config_option(name,
    8366             :                              value,
    8367           0 :                              (superuser() ? PGC_SUSET : PGC_USERSET),
    8368             :                              PGC_S_SESSION,
    8369             :                              is_local ? GUC_ACTION_LOCAL : GUC_ACTION_SET,
    8370             :                              true, 0, false);
    8371             : 
    8372             :     /* get the new current value */
    8373           0 :     new_value = GetConfigOptionByName(name, NULL, false);
    8374             : 
    8375             :     /* Convert return string to text */
    8376           0 :     PG_RETURN_TEXT_P(cstring_to_text(new_value));

    8378             : 
    8379             : 
    8380             : /*
    8381             :  * Common code for DefineCustomXXXVariable subroutines: allocate the
    8382             :  * new variable's config struct and fill in generic fields.
    8383             :  */
    8384             : static struct config_generic *
    8385        3940 : init_custom_variable(const char *name,
    8386             :                      const char *short_desc,
    8387             :                      const char *long_desc,
    8388             :                      GucContext context,
    8389             :                      int flags,
    8390             :                      enum config_type type,
    8391             :                      size_t sz)
    8392             : {
    8393             :     struct config_generic *gen;
    8394             : 
    8395             :     /*
    8396             :      * Only allow custom PGC_POSTMASTER variables to be created during shared
    8397             :      * library preload; any later than that, we can't ensure that the value
    8398             :      * doesn't change after startup.  This is a fatal elog if it happens; just
    8399             :      * erroring out isn't safe because we don't know what the calling loadable
    8400             :      * module might already have hooked into.
    8401             :      */
    8402        3940 :     if (context == PGC_POSTMASTER &&
    8403           0 :         !process_shared_preload_libraries_in_progress)
    8404           0 :         elog(FATAL, "cannot create PGC_POSTMASTER variables after startup");
    8405             : 
    8406             :     /*
    8407             :      * We can't support custom GUC_LIST_QUOTE variables, because the wrong
    8408             :      * things would happen if such a variable were set or pg_dump'd when the
    8409             :      * defining extension isn't loaded.  Again, treat this as fatal because
    8410             :      * the loadable module may be partly initialized already.
    8411             :      */
    8412        3940 :     if (flags & GUC_LIST_QUOTE)
    8413           0 :         elog(FATAL, "extensions cannot define GUC_LIST_QUOTE variables");
    8414             : 
    8415             :     /*
    8416             :      * Before pljava commit 398f3b876ed402bdaec8bc804f29e2be95c75139
    8417             :      * (2015-12-15), two of that module's PGC_USERSET variables facilitated
    8418             :      * trivial escalation to superuser privileges.  Restrict the variables to
    8419             :      * protect sites that have yet to upgrade pljava.
    8420             :      */
    8421        7092 :     if (context == PGC_USERSET &&
    8422        6304 :         (strcmp(name, "pljava.classpath") == 0 ||
    8423        3152 :          strcmp(name, "pljava.vmoptions") == 0))
    8424           0 :         context = PGC_SUSET;
    8425             : 
    8426        3940 :     gen = (struct config_generic *) guc_malloc(ERROR, sz);
    8427        3940 :     memset(gen, 0, sz);
    8428             : 
    8429        3940 :     gen->name = guc_strdup(ERROR, name);
    8430        3940 :     gen->context = context;
    8431        3940 :     gen->group = CUSTOM_OPTIONS;
    8432        3940 :     gen->short_desc = short_desc;
    8433        3940 :     gen->long_desc = long_desc;
    8434        3940 :     gen->flags = flags;
    8435        3940 :     gen->vartype = type;
    8436             : 
    8437        3940 :     return gen;
    8438             : }
    8439             : 
    8440             : /*
    8441             :  * Common code for DefineCustomXXXVariable subroutines: insert the new
    8442             :  * variable into the GUC variable array, replacing any placeholder.
    8443             :  */
    8444             : static void
    8445        3940 : define_custom_variable(struct config_generic *variable)
    8446             : {
    8447        3940 :     const char *name = variable->name;
    8448        3940 :     const char **nameAddr = &name;
    8449             :     struct config_string *pHolder;
    8450             :     struct config_generic **res;
    8451             : 
    8452             :     /*
    8453             :      * See if there's a placeholder by the same name.
    8454             :      */
    8455        3940 :     res = (struct config_generic **) bsearch((void *) &nameAddr,
    8456             :                                              (void *) guc_variables,
    8457             :                                              num_guc_variables,
    8458             :                                              sizeof(struct config_generic *),
    8459             :                                              guc_var_compare);
    8460        3940 :     if (res == NULL)
    8461             :     {
    8462             :         /*
    8463             :          * No placeholder to replace, so we can just add it ... but first,
    8464             :          * make sure it's initialized to its default value.
    8465             :          */
    8466        3940 :         InitializeOneGUCOption(variable);
    8467        3940 :         add_guc_variable(variable, ERROR);
    8468        7880 :         return;
    8469             :     }
    8470             : 
    8471             :     /*
    8472             :      * This better be a placeholder
    8473             :      */
    8474           0 :     if (((*res)->flags & GUC_CUSTOM_PLACEHOLDER) == 0)
    8475           0 :         ereport(ERROR,
    8476             :                 (errcode(ERRCODE_INTERNAL_ERROR),
    8477             :                  errmsg("attempt to redefine parameter \"%s\"", name)));
    8478             : 
    8479           0 :     Assert((*res)->vartype == PGC_STRING);
    8480           0 :     pHolder = (struct config_string *) (*res);
    8481             : 
    8482             :     /*
    8483             :      * First, set the variable to its default value.  We must do this even
    8484             :      * though we intend to immediately apply a new value, since it's possible
    8485             :      * that the new value is invalid.
    8486             :      */
    8487           0 :     InitializeOneGUCOption(variable);
    8488             : 
    8489             :     /*
    8490             :      * Replace the placeholder. We aren't changing the name, so no re-sorting
    8491             :      * is necessary
    8492             :      */
    8493           0 :     *res = variable;
    8494             : 
    8495             :     /*
    8496             :      * Assign the string value(s) stored in the placeholder to the real
    8497             :      * variable.  Essentially, we need to duplicate all the active and stacked
    8498             :      * values, but with appropriate validation and datatype adjustment.
    8499             :      *
    8500             :      * If an assignment fails, we report a WARNING and keep going.  We don't
    8501             :      * want to throw ERROR for bad values, because it'd bollix the add-on
    8502             :      * module that's presumably halfway through getting loaded.  In such cases
    8503             :      * the default or previous state will become active instead.
    8504             :      */
    8505             : 
    8506             :     /* First, apply the reset value if any */
    8507           0 :     if (pHolder->reset_val)
    8508           0 :         (void) set_config_option(name, pHolder->reset_val,
    8509             :                                  pHolder->gen.reset_scontext,
    8510             :                                  pHolder->gen.reset_source,
    8511             :                                  GUC_ACTION_SET, true, WARNING, false);
    8512             :     /* That should not have resulted in stacking anything */
    8513           0 :     Assert(variable->stack == NULL);
    8514             : 
    8515             :     /* Now, apply current and stacked values, in the order they were stacked */
    8516           0 :     reapply_stacked_values(variable, pHolder, pHolder->gen.stack,
    8517           0 :                            *(pHolder->variable),
    8518             :                            pHolder->gen.scontext, pHolder->gen.source);
    8519             : 
    8520             :     /* Also copy over any saved source-location information */
    8521           0 :     if (pHolder->gen.sourcefile)
    8522           0 :         set_config_sourcefile(name, pHolder->gen.sourcefile,
    8523             :                               pHolder->gen.sourceline);
    8524             : 
    8525             :     /*
    8526             :      * Free up as much as we conveniently can of the placeholder structure.
    8527             :      * (This neglects any stack items, so it's possible for some memory to be
    8528             :      * leaked.  Since this can only happen once per session per variable, it
    8529             :      * doesn't seem worth spending much code on.)
    8530             :      */
    8531           0 :     set_string_field(pHolder, pHolder->variable, NULL);
    8532           0 :     set_string_field(pHolder, &pHolder->reset_val, NULL);
    8533             : 
    8534           0 :     free(pHolder);
    8535             : }
    8536             : 
    8537             : /*
    8538             :  * Recursive subroutine for define_custom_variable: reapply non-reset values
    8539             :  *
    8540             :  * We recurse so that the values are applied in the same order as originally.
    8541             :  * At each recursion level, apply the upper-level value (passed in) in the
    8542             :  * fashion implied by the stack entry.
    8543             :  */
    8544             : static void
    8545           0 : reapply_stacked_values(struct config_generic *variable,
    8546             :                        struct config_string *pHolder,
    8547             :                        GucStack *stack,
    8548             :                        const char *curvalue,
    8549             :                        GucContext curscontext, GucSource cursource)
    8550             : {
    8551           0 :     const char *name = variable->name;
    8552           0 :     GucStack   *oldvarstack = variable->stack;
    8553             : 
    8554           0 :     if (stack != NULL)
    8555             :     {
    8556             :         /* First, recurse, so that stack items are processed bottom to top */
    8557           0 :         reapply_stacked_values(variable, pHolder, stack->prev,
    8558           0 :                                stack->prior.val.stringval,
    8559             :                                stack->scontext, stack->source);
    8560             : 
    8561             :         /* See how to apply the passed-in value */
    8562           0 :         switch (stack->state)
    8563             :         {
    8564             :             case GUC_SAVE:
    8565           0 :                 (void) set_config_option(name, curvalue,
    8566             :                                          curscontext, cursource,
    8567             :                                          GUC_ACTION_SAVE, true,
    8568             :                                          WARNING, false);
    8569           0 :                 break;
    8570             : 
    8571             :             case GUC_SET:
    8572           0 :                 (void) set_config_option(name, curvalue,
    8573             :                                          curscontext, cursource,
    8574             :                                          GUC_ACTION_SET, true,
    8575             :                                          WARNING, false);
    8576           0 :                 break;
    8577             : 
    8578             :             case GUC_LOCAL:
    8579           0 :                 (void) set_config_option(name, curvalue,
    8580             :                                          curscontext, cursource,
    8581             :                                          GUC_ACTION_LOCAL, true,
    8582             :                                          WARNING, false);
    8583           0 :                 break;
    8584             : 
    8585             :             case GUC_SET_LOCAL:
    8586             :                 /* first, apply the masked value as SET */
    8587           0 :                 (void) set_config_option(name, stack->masked.val.stringval,
    8588             :                                          stack->masked_scontext, PGC_S_SESSION,
    8589             :                                          GUC_ACTION_SET, true,
    8590             :                                          WARNING, false);
    8591             :                 /* then apply the current value as LOCAL */
    8592           0 :                 (void) set_config_option(name, curvalue,
    8593             :                                          curscontext, cursource,
    8594             :                                          GUC_ACTION_LOCAL, true,
    8595             :                                          WARNING, false);
    8596           0 :                 break;
    8597             :         }
    8598             : 
    8599             :         /* If we successfully made a stack entry, adjust its nest level */
    8600           0 :         if (variable->stack != oldvarstack)
    8601           0 :             variable->stack->nest_level = stack->nest_level;
    8602             :     }
    8603             :     else
    8604             :     {
    8605             :         /*
    8606             :          * We are at the end of the stack.  If the active/previous value is
    8607             :          * different from the reset value, it must represent a previously
    8608             :          * committed session value.  Apply it, and then drop the stack entry
    8609             :          * that set_config_option will have created under the impression that
    8610             :          * this is to be just a transactional assignment.  (We leak the stack
    8611             :          * entry.)
    8612             :          */
    8613           0 :         if (curvalue != pHolder->reset_val ||
    8614           0 :             curscontext != pHolder->gen.reset_scontext ||
    8615           0 :             cursource != pHolder->gen.reset_source)
    8616             :         {
    8617           0 :             (void) set_config_option(name, curvalue,
    8618             :                                      curscontext, cursource,
    8619             :                                      GUC_ACTION_SET, true, WARNING, false);
    8620           0 :             variable->stack = NULL;
    8621             :         }
    8622             :     }
    8623           0 : }

    8859             : /*
    8860             :  * SHOW ALL command

    8862             : static void
    8863           0 : ShowAllGUCConfig(DestReceiver *dest)
    8864             : {
    8865             :     int         i;
    8866             :     TupOutputState *tstate;
    8867             :     TupleDesc   tupdesc;

    8874             :                               TEXTOID, -1, 0);
    8875           0 :     TupleDescInitBuiltinEntry(tupdesc, (AttrNumber) 2, "setting",

    9466             : /*
    9467             :  * show_all_file_settings
    9468             :  *
    9469             :  * Returns a table of all parameter settings in all configuration files
    9470             :  * which includes the config file pathname, the line number, a sequence number
    9471             :  * indicating the order in which the settings were encountered, the parameter
    9472             :  * name and value, a bool showing if the value could be applied, and possibly
    9473             :  * an associated error message.  (For problems such as syntax errors, the
    9474             :  * parameter name/value might be NULL.)
    9475             :  *
    9476             :  * Note: no filtering is done here, instead we depend on the GRANT system
    9477             :  * to prevent unprivileged users from accessing this function or the view
    9478             :  * built on top of it.
    9479             :  */
